• vrai, le sujet de mon ire, c'était de ne point recevoir
de vos nouvelles; partant, je me suis trouvé coi
quand j'ai été convaincu de votre exactitude. Il faut
pourtant là-dessus que je vous en croie sur votre
parole, car je n'ai reçu que votre dernière lettre.
Celle que vous m'écriviez à Rome n'est pas encore
arrivée. J'espère cependant qu'elle ne sera pas per-
due, non plus que d'autres que j'ai reçues par la
même voie, et je l'attends avec impatience, dans
l'espérance d'y trouver des histoires divines.
Il me semble que je vous devrais au moins autant
de compliments sur vos réflexions morales que vous
m'en faites sur mon babil. Vous parlez en homme

sont les relations de voyages. MM. les voyageurs

rarement quittent le ton emphatique en décrivant

resources.content:
On nous fit la faveur de nous faire entrer au Grand Conseil pour voir l'élection du général des galères, charge assez importante. Le Grand Conseil se tient dans une salle immense et bien ornée. Dans le fond est une estrade où sont les places des conseillers et des inquisiteurs d'État, avec le trône du doge au milieu. L'estrade surbaissée tourne tout autour de la salle, et de longs rangs de bancs adossés les uns aux autres et rangés en allées remplissent la salle. Tous les nobles entrèrent là sans ordre et se placèrent. Les robes rouges avoient leurs places marquées, et quelques-unes se dispersèrent en différents lieux de la salle, pour empêcher qu'il ne se fît du bruit dans une si nombreuse assemblée; chose, à mon gré, où ils ne réussirent nullement, puisque l'on y faisoit un sabbat de l'autre monde; aussi ne faisoit-on là que peloter en attendant partie.

Près du grand chancelier, sur l'estrade, il y avoit une urne contenant autant de petites boules qu'il y avoit de personnes, et parmi ces boules un certain nombre de dorées ; chacun tira la sienne. Ceux à qui échurent celles dorées furent les électeurs de la charge en question, avec une grande quantité d'autres qui, par leurs places, étoient électeurs de droit.

Cela fait, nous passâmes dans la salle du scrutin, ornée de la même manière que la première, moins grande, remplie de bancs, l'assemblée y étant moins nombreuse. Les autres électeurs entrèrent l'un après l'autre, saluant jusqu'à terre les précédents, avec une gravité sans pareille. Dès qu'ils eurent tous défilé, le chancelier parut, précédé du corps des secrétaires, gens subalternes, et précédant lui-même le vice-doge; car le doge étoit malade, et c'est le plus vieux des conseillers qui le représente. Mais il ne s'assied pas sur le trône et n'a pas le corno; il l'imitoit tant qu'il pouvoit, ayant mis sur sa tête sa barrette ou bonnet de taffetas noir, dont il ramenoit le sommet par devant en bec à la phrygienne, comme un véritable Anténor. Il étoit suivi de tous les conseillers en robes rouges. Dès qu'il parut, toute l'assemblée se leva; il la salua profondément, sans ôter sa barrette que pour la Quarantie criminelle, lorsqu'il passa devant elle. Seul, de toute l'assemblée, il l'avoit sur la tête.

Il monta sur l'estrade et s'assit. Les sages, grands et autres, se placèrent autour de lui, et sur les ailes le chancelier, à la tête des secrétaires, dont il est le chef. Cette assemblée avoit l'air tout à fait majestueux.

Alors le chancelier se leva et dit que les seigneurs Priuli, Badoar, Donato et Vendramini demandoient la charge en question. Sur-le-champ leurs parents proches se levèrent et sortirent. Immédiatement après, les trois avvogadori prirent chacun un petit évangile, et parcoururent les rangs en faisant toucher à chacun cet évangile du bout du doigt, marque du serment de procéder à l'élection de bonne foi et sans brigue.

Tous ces préalables finis, un grand marsouin d'huissier, ayant mis une paire de lunettes monstrueuses sur un nez qui l'étoit davantage, proclama d'un ton nasillard : « Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli. » À l'instant, une vingtaine de petits enfants rouges, comme ceux de l'hôpital, se dispersèrent par la salle, criant comme des perdus : « Priuli ! Priuli ! » Ils avoient chacun à la main une boîte à deux compartiments, l'un blanc pour nommer, l'autre vert pour refuser; l'ouverture commune étant faite en entonnoir, afin que les assistants ne puissent voir dans laquelle des deux divisions on met la main, et à la ceinture une gibecière pleine de petites ballottes comme des boutons de chemisette; ils en donnèrent une à chaque noble. Ceux-ci la mirent dans celle des enchâtres (compartiments) qu'ils voulurent. Les enfants portèrent leurs boîtes au chancelier, qui versa les ballottes des enchâtres blanches dans un bassin, et jeta les autres. On ballotta de même les trois autres concurrents; puis on compta les suffrages. Donato fut élu, et nous sortîmes.

Tout cela fut fait avec une rapidité surprenante, et en moins de temps qu'il n'y en a que je vous en écris; mais c'étoit une vraie comédie que de voir, en sortant, les prosternations de Donato et les baisers de nourrice qu'on lui donnoit. D'honneur, ils sonnoient à se faire entendre au milieu de la place.

The invitation had arrived with the morning tide, a discreet note delivered by one of the Ambassador’s liveried gondoliers. “A rare opportunity, Monsieur de Brosses, to witness the heart of the Republic’s governance.” It was the election of the General of the Galleys, a significant charge, as I understood it, overseeing Venice’s naval might, or what remained of it. Such a favour was not to be refused, especially given the Comte de Froulay’s generous hospitality and the general difficulty strangers encountered in penetrating the inner sanctum of Venetian nobility.

My companion and I, dressed in our most respectable travelling attire, were guided through the labyrinthine passages of the Ducal Palace. The grand staircase, aptly named ‘of the Giants’ with its colossal statues of Mars and Neptune, seemed to dwarf us even further as we ascended, my gaze momentarily caught by the intricate violet and white marble. We were led to the Sala del Maggior Consiglio, an immense chamber, far grander than any royal hall I had seen in France, though perhaps not as finely kept. It was a cavernous space, adorned with monumental canvases depicting Venice’s glorious past, their gilded frames catching the diffused light filtering through high windows. Long rows of benches, upholstered in a faded, rich fabric, stretched across the floor, facing a raised estrade at the far end.

Yet, despite the grandeur, the scene was far from solemn. Nobles, a sea of black robes and periwigs, milled about without apparent order, a murmur rising to a cacophony that assaulted the ears. It was, as I later described it, a veritable 'sabbat de l'autre monde'. They jostled, whispered, and gesticulated, their voices echoing off the painted ceilings. Some, distinguished by their scarlet robes, presumably the Sages and more senior Councillors, attempted to impose some semblance of quiet, but their efforts were largely in vain. It seemed the assembly, for all its pomp, was content to engage in lively chatter, like boys at play, awaiting the commencement of a game. I noted several gentlemen engaged in earnest, yet hushed, discussions, their hands frequently reaching for their barrette to emphasize a point, their gazes darting across the room, no doubt weighing alliances and calculating prospects. The air was thick with anticipation, a scent of old wood, beeswax, and the faintest hint of the lagoon’s briny breath.

Our host, the Ambassador, leaned in to offer a whispered explanation of the proceedings. "First, Monsieur, they must select the electors themselves. A curious custom, to be sure, but one that ensures a certain... unpredictability." He gestured towards the estrade where, near the Grand Chancellor, a large, ornate urn stood. It was made of polished bronze, glinting dully in the light, and appeared weighty, almost ancient. A hush, albeit a fragile one, began to fall as the first stage of the election commenced. One by one, or in small groups, the nobles approached the urn. Each reached in, his hand disappearing into the dark maw, to draw forth a small, smooth ball. Most were plain, of white wax or wood, signifying nothing more than participation. But a select few, as I soon observed, were gilded, catching the light as they were withdrawn. Those who drew a golden ball were hailed by their immediate neighbours with quiet nods of congratulation, a slight widening of the eyes, or a subtle, almost imperceptible, smile. These, along with a pre-appointed number of dignitaries who held the right by virtue of their office, would form the electoral college. The process was swift, a practiced ritual, and soon, a distinct group of nobles, now bearing the weight of their temporary office, began to separate themselves from the general throng.

Once the initial selection was complete, a new sense of purpose settled over the assembly. We were then directed to another, smaller hall, equally well-appointed, though its dimensions lent it a more intimate, and perhaps more serious, atmosphere. This was the Sala dello Scrutinio, where the actual voting would take place. The electors, now a more focused body, entered one by one, each bowing deeply to those already seated, a gesture of profound respect that contrasted sharply with the earlier disorder. Their movements were measured, their expressions grave, as if each step carried the weight of the Republic’s future.

Then, a procession. First, the body of secretaries, men of sober mien in dark robes, their faces etched with the diligence of their office, clearing a path. Following them, with a quiet dignity, came the Grand Chancellor, his presence commanding, his scarlet robe a splash of colour against the prevailing black. And behind him, the Vice-Doge. The true Doge, as we knew, was indisposed, confined to his apartments in the palace. His representative, the eldest of the Councillors, did his utmost to embody the Doge's authority. He wore the black taffeta barrette, pulled forward to a Phrygian point, giving him the appearance of an ancient Antenor, a figure of venerable wisdom. Yet, the absence of the Doge’s distinctive corno, the ducal cap, was a subtle but poignant reminder of his delegated authority. As he passed the seated Quarantia Criminale, he offered a profound bow, and only then, for that brief moment, did his hand move to his barrette, a gesture of deference to that powerful judicial body. He alone, in that entire assembly, wore his head covering throughout.

The Vice-Doge ascended the estrade and took his place, not on the Doge’s throne, which remained empty, but in the chair adjacent to it. Around him, the Sages, the Grandi, and other high-ranking officials arranged themselves, their rich robes forming a formidable semicircle. On the wings, the Chancellor positioned himself at the head of the secretaries, a silent phalanx of administrative power. The assembly, though smaller than the initial gathering, exuded an undeniable majesty, a quiet strength that spoke volumes of the Republic's enduring institutions.

The Chancellor rose, his voice clear and resonant, breaking the expectant silence. He formally announced the candidates for the charge of General of the Galleys: "The most illustrious lords Priuli, Badoar, Donato, and Vendramini seek this office." Immediately, a stir went through the hall. Close relatives of each candidate, bound by ancient custom, rose from their seats and quietly exited the chamber. This was a crucial point of Venetian probity, ensuring that no family ties could sway the immediate electoral process. Following this, three Avvogadori della Comune, guardians of the Republic’s laws, each holding a small, leather-bound Gospel, began to circulate among the electors. With solemn faces, they held out the sacred text, and each elector, in turn, touched it with the tip of his finger, swearing an oath to proceed with the election in good faith, free from intrigue or corruption. It was a powerful, symbolic act, a moment of profound commitment amidst the political machinations.

With the oath administered, the final stage began. A burly usher, whom De Brosses would later comically describe as a "marsouin" (porpoise) owing to his stout build and a rather prominent nose, now further exaggerated by a pair of truly monstrous spectacles, stepped forward. In a surprisingly reedy, almost nasal voice, he proclaimed: "V'excellentissimo signore Luca Priuli!" At once, the hall erupted, not with shouts from the nobles, but with the shrill, enthusiastic cries of children. A score of young boys, clad in bright red tunics reminiscent of the orphanage uniform, burst into the hall, scattering amongst the electors like a flock of excited sparrows. "Priuli! Priuli!" they chanted, their voices echoing with an almost theatrical fervor. Each boy carried a small wooden box, divided into two compartments: one white for "yes," one green for "no." The opening was funnel-shaped, ingeniously designed to prevent anyone from seeing into which compartment an elector placed his hand. From pouches at their belts, they distributed small, smooth ballotte, like shirt buttons, to each noble.

The electors, with practiced ease, took their ballotte. I watched as they approached the children, their faces impassive, and, with a swift, almost imperceptible movement, dropped their vote into the chosen compartment. There was a quiet intensity to this act, a silent judgment delivered. The red-clad children, once their rounds were complete, returned to the estrade, presenting their boxes to the Chancellor. He, in turn, carefully emptied the ballotte from the white compartments into a large silver basin, discarding the contents of the green. This precise ritual was repeated for each of the other candidates: Badoar, Vendramini, and finally, Donato.

The counting of the suffrages was swift, a flurry of motion from the secretaries. The Chancellor announced the result with a grave voice: Donato was elected. A wave of murmurs, a mix of satisfaction and disappointment, swept through the hall. As we prepared to depart, the real spectacle began. Donato, the newly elected General, was immediately surrounded by a throng of well-wishers. He bowed, deeply, repeatedly, his body almost touching the floor in exaggerated prosternations. And then came the "baisers de nourrice"—loud, smacking kisses planted on his cheeks by his supporters, so resounding that, as De Brosses remarked, they could surely be heard across the Piazza San Marco. It was a theatrical, almost farcical display of congratulations, a vivid coda to the Republic's solemn, yet often boisterous, political theatre. We exited, leaving the triumphant Donato to his embraces, the air still buzzing with the rapid-fire conclusion of this most Venetian of elections.

[HOW TO USE]: Here is the event text that must be augmented. It comes from Charles de Brosses's "Lettres familières d'Italie". Please bridge the gaps between the events that de Brosses describes in a plausible way.
On nous fit la faveur de nous faire entrer au Grand Conseil pour voir l'élection du général des galères, charge assez importante. Le Grand Conseil se tient dans une salle immense et bien ornée. Dans le fond est une estrade où sont les places des conseillers et des inquisiteurs d'État, avec le trône du doge au milieu. L'estrade surbaissée tourne tout autour de la salle, et de longs rangs de bancs adossés les uns aux autres et rangés en allées remplissent la salle. Tous les nobles entrèrent là sans ordre et se placèrent. Les robes rouges avoient leurs places marquées, et quelques-unes se dispersèrent en différents lieux de la salle, pour empêcher qu'il ne se fît du bruit dans une si nombreuse assemblée; chose, à mon gré, où ils ne réussirent nullement, puisque l'on y faisoit un sabbat de l'autre monde; aussi ne faisoit-on là que peloter en attendant partie.

Près du grand chancelier, sur l'estrade, il y avoit une urne contenant autant de petites boules qu'il y avoit de personnes, et parmi ces boules un certain nombre de dorées ; chacun tira la sienne. Ceux à qui échurent celles dorées furent les électeurs de la charge en question, avec une grande quantité d'autres qui, par leurs places, étoient électeurs de droit.

Cela fait, nous passâmes dans la salle du scrutin, ornée de la même manière que la première, moins grande, remplie de bancs, l'assemblée y étant moins nombreuse. Les autres électeurs entrèrent l'un après l'autre, saluant jusqu'à terre les précédents, avec une gravité sans pareille. Dès qu'ils eurent tous défilé, le chancelier parut, précédé du corps des secrétaires, gens subalternes, et précédant lui-même le vice-doge; car le doge étoit malade, et c'est le plus vieux des conseillers qui le représente. Mais il ne s'assied pas sur le trône et n'a pas le corno; il l'imitoit tant qu'il pouvoit, ayant mis sur sa tête sa barrette ou bonnet de taffetas noir, dont il ramenoit le sommet par devant en bec à la phrygienne, comme un véritable Anténor. Il étoit suivi de tous les conseillers en robes rouges. Dès qu'il parut, toute l'assemblée se leva; il la salua profondément, sans ôter sa barrette que pour la Quarantie criminelle, lorsqu'il passa devant elle. Seul, de toute l'assemblée, il l'avoit sur la tête.

Il monta sur l'estrade et s'assit. Les sages, grands et autres, se placèrent autour de lui, et sur les ailes le chancelier, à la tête des secrétaires, dont il est le chef. Cette assemblée avoit l'air tout à fait majestueux.

Alors le chancelier se leva et dit que les seigneurs Priuli, Badoar, Donato et Vendramini demandoient la charge en question. Sur-le-champ leurs parents proches se levèrent et sortirent. Immédiatement après, les trois avvogadori prirent chacun un petit évangile, et parcoururent les rangs en faisant toucher à chacun cet évangile du bout du doigt, marque du serment de procéder à l'élection de bonne foi et sans brigue.

Tous ces préalables finis, un grand marsouin d'huissier, ayant mis une paire de lunettes monstrueuses sur un nez qui l'étoit davantage, proclama d'un ton nasillard : « Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli. » À l'instant, une vingtaine de petits enfants rouges, comme ceux de l'hôpital, se dispersèrent par la salle, criant comme des perdus : « Priuli ! Priuli ! » Ils avoient chacun à la main une boîte à deux compartiments, l'un blanc pour nommer, l'autre vert pour refuser; l'ouverture commune étant faite en entonnoir, afin que les assistants ne puissent voir dans laquelle des deux divisions on met la main, et à la ceinture une gibecière pleine de petites ballottes comme des boutons de chemisette; ils en donnèrent une à chaque noble. Ceux-ci la mirent dans celle des enchâtres (compartiments) qu'ils voulurent. Les enfants portèrent leurs boîtes au chancelier, qui versa les ballottes des enchâtres blanches dans un bassin, et jeta les autres. On ballotta de même les trois autres concurrents; puis on compta les suffrages. Donato fut élu, et nous sortîmes.

Tout cela fut fait avec une rapidité surprenante, et en moins de temps qu'il n'y en a que je vous en écris; mais c'étoit une vraie comédie que de voir, en sortant, les prosternations de Donato et les baisers de nourrice qu'on lui donnoit. D'honneur, ils sonnoient à se faire entendre au milieu de la place.

Our ambassador, the Comte de Froulay, a man of considerable influence and good humor, had secured us a rare privilege: an invitation to witness a session of the Great Council. This was not a mere formality, but the election of the General of the Galleys, a post of no small importance to a maritime republic. Sainte-Palaye and I, ever keen observers, prepared ourselves for an experience far removed from the salon discussions we usually frequented.

The morning began, not in the hushed corridors of diplomacy, but amidst the vibrant clamor of the Piazzetta San Marco. It was a spectacle in itself, what the Venetians call the *Broglio*. Though the hour was still early, the square buzzed with a peculiar energy. Nobles, identifiable by their mandatory black *vesta* — long gowns that lent them a solemn, almost clerical air, though many sported fashionable, powdered wigs that seemed anachronistic with their ancient attire — moved with a purpose. They were not merely strolling; they were engaged in a silent, yet intensely active, political dance. Candidates, or their agents, stood on one side, their gazes sweeping the crowd for those patricians whose votes they needed. Electors, in turn, would approach with deep bows, exchanging whispered words, a discreet kiss to a sleeve or a stole, a hand clasp, a barely perceptible nod. The air was thick with unspoken promises, veiled requests for support, and the subtle exchange of influence. I observed several *Barnabotti*, those impoverished nobles living off their inherited right to vote, clustered together, their eyes darting, ready to sell their single commodity to the highest bidder in terms of future favors or a generous meal. It was a fascinating tableau of power and dependency, all conducted beneath a veneer of exaggerated politeness, a testament to the Republic's intricate, yet deeply human, political machinery.

Suddenly, the deep, resonant clang of the *Trottiera* bell cut through the morning's murmur. It was the signal, urging the patricians to gather. The crowd on the Piazzetta began to move, a flowing tide of black robes and bobbing wigs, all heading towards the Giants' Staircase of the Doge's Palace. We joined the stream, ascending the grand marble steps, a path trodden by centuries of Venetian power.

The Sala del Maggior Consiglio, when we entered, was indeed immense and richly adorned, just as I had heard. Even in August, the sheer volume of the space and the press of bodies made the air heavy, though the large windows offered some respite with views of the lagoon. The ceiling, a riot of gold leaf and painted allegories, seemed to press down with the weight of history, particularly Veronese's "The Triumph of Venice." At the far end, above the raised tribune of the Signoria, Tintoretto’s vast "Il Paradiso" loomed, its darkened canvas forming a severe, almost ominous backdrop to the proceedings. The hall, capable of holding well over a thousand patricians, was already filled with a constant, low hum, a "sabbat de l'autre monde," as I noted, that made official announcements almost impossible to discern from the distant benches. Nobles, seemingly without formal order, found their places on the long rows of benches that ran parallel to the walls, leaving a wide central aisle. Those in red robes — the high magistrates, the *Savi*, the *Capi di Quarantia* — had their designated seats, though some strategically dispersed themselves, ostensibly to maintain order, but perhaps also to better gauge the mood of the assembly or to conduct last-minute whispers. In truth, their efforts against the general din were futile; it was an unruly gathering, a perpetual "peloter en attendant partie" of jostling and murmuring.

Near the grand Chancellor, upon the elevated platform, stood a finely carved wooden urn. It contained a number of small balls, one for each patrician present, a select few of which were gilded. This was the first, crucial step: the sortition of the electors. One by one, each noble approached the urn. A small boy, perhaps eight years of age, dressed in a simple white tunic, the *Ballottino*, stood beside it. With an air of solemn innocence that belied the tension in the room, he plunged his hand into the urn and drew out a ball for each passing noble. A collective intake of breath, a slight lean forward, a murmur of anticipation accompanied each draw. A gold ball meant participation in the next, more secretive stage of the election; a silver ball meant a return to the benches to await the final vote. Those who drew gold balls, along with certain high-ranking officials who were electors by right of their office, were separated from the main body of the Council.

With the initial selection completed, we were guided to the Sala dello Scrutinio, an adjacent hall, similarly adorned but noticeably smaller and less crowded. The chosen electors, now a more focused assembly, entered one after another, each performing deep, almost theatrical bows to those already present, a display of unparalleled gravity that underscored the importance of their task.

Finally, the grand procession of the Republic's highest dignitaries made its entrance. The Chancellor, a figure of considerable administrative power, appeared first, followed by a retinue of secretaries, their black robes a stark contrast to the deeper hues of the magistrates. He, in turn, preceded the Vice-Doge. The true Doge, Pisani, was unfortunately indisposed, and so the oldest of the ducal counselors, a venerable man whose face bore the marks of countless councils, represented him. He did not, of course, sit upon the ducal throne, nor did he wear the distinctive corno, the Doge's cap. Instead, he did his best to imitate the ducal presence, his black taffeta barrette, pulled forward into a Phrygian-like point, giving him the appearance of an ancient Antenor. He was flanked by all the other red-robed counselors. As this august group appeared, the entire assembly rose in deference. The Vice-Doge, with a profound bow, acknowledged them all, removing his barrette only once, in a gesture of respect, as he passed before the bench of the Quarantia Criminelle. He alone, of all present, retained his headwear throughout the procession.

He then ascended the estrade and took his place, not on the Doge's throne, but beside it. The *Savi*—the wise men—the *Capi dei Dieci*, and other high officials settled around him, while the Chancellor positioned himself at the head of his secretaries on one of the side wings. The assembly, now properly constituted, exuded an air of solemn majesty, a stark contrast to the earlier cacophony.

The Chancellor rose once more, his voice, though still somewhat lost in the vastness of the room, now commanded greater attention. He announced the names of the gentlemen who sought the important charge of General of the Galleys: "The illustrious Signori Priuli, Badoar, Donato, and Vendramini." Immediately, a rustle went through the room as their closest relatives, bound by ancient custom, rose from their seats and withdrew from the hall, preventing any appearance of undue influence. Following this, the three *Avvogadori*—state advocates responsible for upholding the law—each took a small Gospel. They moved through the ranks, ensuring that every elector touched the holy book with the tip of his finger, a solemn oath to proceed with the election in good faith, free from faction or *briga*.

With these preliminaries concluded, a large, corpulent usher, whom I could only describe as a "marsouin," adjusted a monstrous pair of spectacles upon an even more prodigious nose. His voice, a nasal drone, cut through the remaining murmurs as he proclaimed: "Vexcellentissimo Signore Luca Priuli!" At that instant, a score of small boys, dressed in red tunics like those from the *Ospedali*—the orphanages—dispersed themselves throughout the hall. They were the true *Ballottini* for this stage of the election, crying out like lost souls, "Priuli! Priuli!" Each child carried a small wooden box with two compartments, one marked in white for "yes" (to name) and the other in green for "no" (to refuse). The common opening, shaped like a funnel, ensured the secrecy of each vote. From a pouch at their waist, they offered each noble a small, silent linen ball, the *balotta*. Each patrician took a ball and, with a practiced hand, dropped it into the compartment of their choice. The *Ballottini* then dutifully carried their boxes to the Chancellor, who emptied the white balls into a large basin for counting, discarding the green ones.

The same process was repeated for the three other candidates: Badoar, Vendramini, and finally, Donato. The rhythmic cries of the children, the solemn movements of the nobles, the clatter of the small balls—it all contributed to a unique, almost theatrical ritual. Once all votes were cast, the suffrages were counted. The Chancellor, after a brief consultation, announced the result: "The most excellent Signore Donato is elected!"

And just as swiftly as it had begun, it was over. We, the foreign observers, were ushered out. The entire procedure, from the first draw of the gold balls to the final announcement, had unfolded with a surprising rapidity, far quicker than the time it took me to recount it in my journal. It truly was a comedy to behold the scene that followed: the newly elected Donato, bowing profoundly, receiving hearty congratulations and "baisers de nourrice"—wet, smacking kisses that echoed loudly, even amidst the bustling square outside. It was a vivid, sometimes boisterous, demonstration of Venetian politics, a blend of ancient ritual, shrewd maneuvering, and undeniable theatricality.

Simulation Data Sheet: The Great Council of Venice (1740)


Document Objective

This document serves as a knowledge base for a text-based simulation (LLM). It details the mechanics, atmosphere, and procedures of the Maggior Consiglio (Great Council) in 1740, based on the institutional analysis of Amelot de La Houssaye and historical data regarding the daily life of the Republic.

1. The Space: La Sala del Maggior Consiglio

For the simulation, the space acts as a constraining environment that dictates movement and social interaction.

Architecture and Symbolism

Dimensions: A massive hall (53m x 25m) free of supporting columns, capable of holding between 1,000 and 2,000 patricians.
The Ceiling: Heavy with gold leaf and paintings (notably Veronese’s The Triumph of Venice). It serves as a constant reminder of the divine and state hierarchy.
The East Wall (Il Paradiso): Dominated by Tintoretto’s immense canvas, located above the Signoria's tribune. By 1740, the painting had darkened with time, creating a severe backdrop behind the Doge.
The Tribune (La Signoria): A raised platform where the Doge, his six counselors, and the three chiefs of the Quarantia sit. They physically overlook the assembly.
The Benches (Banchi): Arranged in double rows parallel to the walls, leaving a vast central aisle empty for voting procedures.1

Annexed Spaces (Crucial for Intrigue)

The Liagò: A closed loggia or terrace adjacent to the hall. It is a "decompression" zone where nobles withdraw to speak freely, negotiate votes away from the Signoria’s gaze, or escape the stifling air of the main hall.2
The Sala dello Scrutinio: An adjacent hall often used for counting votes or secondary balloting procedures.3

Sensory Atmosphere

Acoustics: The sheer volume of the hall and the number of participants create a constant background hum (buzzing). Official readings by the Chancellor are often inaudible to those seated at the far ends.
Light and Temperature: The hall is lit by large windows facing the lagoon. In winter, it is notoriously freezing (nobles keep their fur-lined cloaks on). In summer, the heat and the proximity of bodies make the air oppressive.4

2. The Actors: Patrician Sociology (1740)

The simulation must distinguish between three classes of nobles, who are legally equal but economically and politically divided.

The Three Classes

The "Case Vecchie" and the Rich: Historic families or immense new fortunes. They monopolize high executive offices (Savi, Council of Ten, Ambassadors). They use the Great Council to validate their power, though real decisions are made in the Senate.5
The Middle Nobility: They aim for judicial (Quarantie) and administrative offices. They are often legalistic and attached to procedure.
The Barnabotti (The Noble Plebs):
Definition: Impoverished nobles, often living in the parish of San Barnaba. They have lost their fortunes but retain their vote in the Council.6
Role in Simulation: They constitute an electoral maneuver mass. Barred from trade and manual labor, their only "commodity" is their vote. They are known to be unruly and to sell their suffrage in exchange for informal gratuities (protection, loans, meals).7

Costume (Visual Code)

The Vesta (Toga): Mandatory for all. A long black gown with large sleeves (a comito). In winter, it is lined with fur; in summer, it is made of light silk.9
The Stola (Stole): A band of black cloth worn over the left shoulder. Its width and lining indicate rank (ordinary for a simple noble, wide and fur-lined for Senators and Councilors).10
The Wig: By 1740, the use of the powdered wig is generalized, creating an anachronistic contrast between the medieval costume (toga) and the Rococo hairstyle. High, voluminous wigs are a sign of fashion and wealth.

3. The Political Ritual


Before the Session: The Broglio

Location: The Piazzetta San Marco, before the bell rings.
Action: This is the time for electoral solicitation. Candidates ("solicitors") stand on one side, electors on the other.12
Gestures: Open campaigning is forbidden by law. Everything occurs through codes of exaggerated politeness: deep bows, kissing of the sleeve or stole, and whispered requests for support ("Mi raccomando").12
The Trottiera: The specific bell that announces the imminent start of the session, urging latecomers to hasten to the palace.4

During the Session: Voting and Chance

The Venetian system, detailed by Amelot de La Houssaye, relies on a complex mix of Sortition (to prevent factions) and Election (to ensure competence).

The Tools

The Ballottino: A boy aged 8 to 10, often dressed in white, tasked with drawing balls from the urns to guarantee the innocence of chance.3
The Bussole (Urns): Wooden structures allowing for secret voting. The noble inserts his hand and drops his ball into a hidden tube (the "Yes" tube or "No" tube).
The Balls (Balote): Small balls made of compressed linen (for silence).
Gold: Winning ball (for sortition).
Silver: Losing ball.
White / Red (or Green): Used for voting "Yes" or "No" during legislative or judicial scrutinies.3

The "Four Hands" Procedure (Election of Magistrates)

This is the standard procedure for electing state officials.14
The Sortition: Each noble passes before an urn. The Ballottino draws a ball for him. If he gets a Gold ball, he becomes an Elector. This continues until 36 electors are chosen.14
The Division: The 36 electors are isolated and divided into 4 groups of 9, called "Hands" (Mani).
The Nomination (Secret): Each "Hand," isolated in a separate room, must agree (by a majority of 6 out of 9) to propose one candidate for the vacant post.
The General Ballot: The 4 names proposed (one by each "Hand") are announced to the Great Council. The entire assembly then votes for or against each candidate. The one with the most votes wins.14

4. Simulation Data Cards


Card A: Sequence of Actions (Sunday Routine)

10:00 AM - Broglio: Social interaction on the Piazza. Informal negotiations.
10:30 AM - Trottiera: Sound signal. Crowd movement towards the Giants' Staircase.
11:00 AM - Installation: Entry into the hall. Barnabotti seek strategic seats or cluster together.
11:30 AM - Reading: The Chancellor reads the list of vacant posts. Ambient hubbub.
12:00 PM - Lottery (Ballottino): Slow procession before the urn. Tension of the Gold/Silver draw.
1:00 PM - Conclave of the 4 Hands: Session suspension for the 36 electors. Others wait, chat in the Liagò.
2:00 PM - Final Vote: Procession to the Bussole to validate candidates.

Card B: Tension Variables

These modifiers can be used to generate incidents or intrigues in the simulation.
Cold/Heat: Impatience factor. Can push nobles to rush a vote or leave the session early (if the quorum is not threatened).
Vote Selling: A player may be approached by an agent of a rich family: "A dinner invitation in exchange for a white ball for candidate Cornaro."6
Procedural Error: If the Ballottino makes a mistake or an urn is improperly closed, the Quarantie (judges) must intervene, creating a dramatic interruption.

Dès qu'ils eurent tous défilé, le chancelier parut, précédé du corps des secrétaires, gens subalternes, et précédant lui-même le vice-doge; car le doge étoit malade, et c'est le plus vieux des conseillers qui le représente. Mais il ne s'assied pas sur le trône et n'a pas le corno; il l'imitoit tant qu'il pouvoit, ayant mis sur sa tête sa barrette ou bonnet de taffetas noir, dont il ramenoit le sommet par devant en bec à la phrygienne, comme un véritable Anténor. Il étoit suivi de tous les conseillers en robes rouges. Dès qu'il parut, toute l'assemblée se leva; il la salua profondément, sans ôter sa barrette que pour la Quarantie criminelle, lorsqu'il passa devant elle. Seul, de toute l'assemblée, il l'avoit sur la tête.

Il monta sur l'estrade et s'assit. Les sages, grands et autres, se placèrent autour de lui, et sur les ailes le chancelier, à la tête des secrétaires, dont il est le chef. Cette assemblée avoit l'air tout à fait majestueux.

Alors le chancelier se leva et dit que les seigneurs Priuli, Badoar, Donato et Vendramini demandoient la charge en question. Sur-le-champ leurs parents proches se levèrent et sortirent. Immédiatement après, les trois avvogadori prirent chacun un petit évangile, et parcoururent les rangs en faisant toucher à chacun cet évangile du bout du doigt, marque du serment de procéder à l'élection de bonne foi et sans brigue.

Tous ces préalables finis, un grand marsouin d'huissier, ayant mis une paire de lunettes monstrueuses sur un nez qui l'étoit davantage, proclama d'un ton nasillard : « Vexcellentissimo signore Luca Priuli. » À l'instant, une vingtaine de petits enfants rouges, comme ceux de l'hôpital, se dispersèrent par la salle, criant comme des perdus : « Priuli ! Priuli ! » Ils avoient chacun à la main une boîte à deux compartiments, l'un blanc pour nommer, l'autre vert pour refuser; l'ouverture commune étant faite en entonnoir, afin que les assistants ne puissent voir dans laquelle des deux divisions on met la main, et à la ceinture une gibecière pleine de petites ballottes comme des boutons de chemisette; ils en donnèrent une à chaque noble. Ceux-ci la mirent dans celle des enchâtres (compartiments) qu'ils voulurent. Les enfants portèrent leurs boîtes au chancelier, qui versa les ballottes des enchâtres blanches dans un bassin, et jeta les autres. On ballotta de même les trois autres concurrents; puis on compta les suffrages. Donato fut élu, et nous sortîmes.

Tout cela fut fait avec une rapidité surprenante, et en moins de temps qu'il n'y en a que je vous en écris; mais c'étoit une vraie comédie que de voir, en sortant, les prosternations de Donato et les baisers de nourrice qu'on lui donnoit. D'honneur, ils sonnoient à se faire entendre au milieu de la place.

October 3rd.

The morning mist, clinging low over the water, had barely begun to lift as I set out, the air still carrying the damp chill of the Venetian night. I had risen early, eager to continue my explorations, particularly to see Il Redentore on the Giudecca. My gondolier, a quiet fellow named Marco, whose face was weathered by sun and salt, deftly navigated the narrow canals, his oar dipping with a rhythmic hush that was the city’s true heartbeat. We passed under low bridges, the stone cool and damp above us, and by the darkened ground floors of palaces where the faint sounds of waking life – a clatter of pottery, a murmured greeting – were just beginning. As we emerged into the broader stretch of the Giudecca Canal, the church of Il Redentore appeared across the water, its grand, serene façade slowly emerging from the receding mist, catching the first pale rays of the rising sun.

It stood there, a vision of Palladian genius, its lines severe yet harmonious, a testament to the architect’s profound understanding of classical forms. I had read of it, seen engravings, but to stand before it, even from a distance across the water, was to feel its presence. Marco brought the gondola alongside the quay, and I stepped out, my gaze fixed on the church. The façade, indeed, surpassed even that of San Giorgio Maggiore in its balance and clarity. Palladio, I mused, was a man truly steeped in the antique spirit, yet forced to build for an age that had lost much of that grandeur. He wrestled with the conventions of his time, striving to infuse Christian sacred spaces with the noble simplicity of ancient temples. In Il Redentore, he seemed to have achieved a rare success, avoiding the subtle incongruities I had noted in San Giorgio. It was a triumph of will and vision, a master’s refusal to yield to the "narrow, petty spirit" of his contemporaries.

Inside, the admiration only deepened. The vast, uncluttered space, the elegant proportions, the light filtering through high windows – it all spoke of Palladio’s hand. Even the altars, often left to lesser artists, bore his distinctive touch, each a miniature architectural composition. Yet, a shadow of disappointment fell as my eyes sought the niches intended for statuary. Instead of the marble or bronze figures that would have completed Palladio’s vision, I found crude wooden carvings, flat and painted, glaringly out of place. They were simple, almost rustic, betraying a lack of means or perhaps a shift in artistic priorities. It was a common enough sight in churches, but here, in a structure of such refined beauty, it felt like a betrayal of the grand design. One could almost hear Palladio sighing from the grave at such a compromise.

Leaving Il Redentore, I wandered through the labyrinthine streets, my mind still turning over Palladio’s legacy. My path led me, almost by chance, to the church of San Pietro di Castello, a place less frequented by the casual visitor. The Capuchin friars, known for their austerity, had nonetheless lavished considerable attention on a side altar dedicated to Saint Francis. It was a curious sight, a blend of humble devotion and unexpected artistry. Only the Corinthian capitals, flanking the altar, were of stone. All else, at first glance, appeared to be covered in a rich, almost opulent embroidery, styled in the intricate arabesque patterns so favored in the East, but rendered with a distinctly Venetian flourish.

I approached, drawn by the shimmering details. The broad tendrils and foliage seemed to glow with gold, woven with a skill that suggested immense labor and precious materials. My initial thought was of the wealth such an adornment must have required, perhaps donated by some pious noble family. But as I drew nearer, my eyes, accustomed now to the subtle deceptions of art and craft, discerned an ingenious trick. What I had taken for gold was, in fact, straw, flattened and meticulously glued onto paper, following intricate outlines. The background, beneath these straw patterns, was painted in vibrant, lively colors, creating an illusion of depth and richness. The effect was remarkably pretty, a testament to the Capuchins' resourcefulness and artistic sensibility. To achieve such variety and tact with a material so utterly without intrinsic value, yet to create a design that, if executed in genuine gold thread, would have cost thousands of ducats – it was a marvel of imitation. I considered its potential, thinking how such a technique might be advantageously applied elsewhere, a lesson in making much from little.

Later that afternoon, as I strolled along one of the bustling quays, perhaps near the Riva del Carbon, where the Grand Canal narrowed, I often found myself observing a particular spectacle. A small man, with an unassuming, almost sedate appearance, held court before a shifting crowd of auditors. He was a storyteller, a "cantastorie," his voice a rapid-fire torrent of Venetian dialect. Though I understood scarcely a word, his performance was captivating. The audience, composed mostly of porters, fishermen, and market vendors – the lowest class, as I noted – would occasionally smile, a flicker of appreciation crossing their faces, but never erupt into laughter. It was a serious business, this storytelling. The man’s gestures were what truly held my attention: an admirable variety, precise and economical, each movement of his hands, each tilt of his head, conveying meaning that transcended the barrier of language. It was a performance born of art and reflection, honed over countless repetitions, a silent language understood by all. He was not ridiculous, not striking in a flamboyant way, but possessed a quiet authority, an almost scholarly precision in his delivery, that commanded respect even from those who merely passed by.

My next destination was the Conservatorio dei Mendicanti, a renowned institution. With my map, a precious possession in this city of bewildering twists and turns, I plunged into the "strangest labyrinth" of narrow calli and sudden campi. The directions were precise, yet the sheer density of buildings, the unexpected cul-de-sacs, and the constant hum of life made navigation a delightful challenge. Finally, I arrived at the church, its façade less ornate than Redentore, but with a quiet dignity.

The church was already filled with an expectant crowd, a mixture of the curious public and serious connoisseurs. Behind a tall, decorative grating, the famed "ladies" of the conservatorio were preparing to perform an oratorio. The air thrummed with anticipation. When the music began, it was, as promised, magnificent. The voices were truly superb, soaring with a purity and power that transcended the physical barrier of the grating. An alto, singing the part of King Saul, possessed a voice of such depth and resonance that I had never before encountered its like. Certain passages of the music were excessively beautiful, stirring the soul with their melodic invention. The words, though Latin, were rendered with a distinctly Italianate pronunciation, almost "laughably Italianized" in places, yet perfectly adapted for the singing, bending to the melodic line with effortless grace. Music, here in Venice, truly had a boundless field to explore.

The enjoyment, however, was not without its vexations. The "accursed Maestro di Capella," rather than conducting with subtlety, chose to beat time with a rolled sheet of music against the grating. It was a loud, conspicuous thwack, as if he were instructing a class of recalcitrant schoolboys. The girls, I felt, had surely rehearsed the piece to perfection, rendering his noisy intervention entirely unnecessary. His insistent thumping shattered the delicate atmosphere, destroying the impression much as if one were to stick "scarlet patches on the joints" of a beautiful statue to make it more intelligible. The foreign, intrusive sound was a jarring discord in the harmony. This man, a musician himself, seemed utterly insensible to the damage he inflicted. Or, more likely, he wished to assert his presence, to make his authority felt through this impropriety, when his true value should have been perceived through the flawless execution of his pupils. I had often attributed such crude displays to the French, but here, it seemed, the Italians were equally prone, and the public, astonishingly, appeared accustomed to it. It was a peculiar Venetian paradox: that which marred the enjoyment was, in some strange way, considered an integral part of the experience. It was not the first time I had observed this odd acceptance of imperfection in the pursuit of art here.

Oct. 3.
The church Il Redentore is a large and beautiful work by Palladio, with a façade even more worthy of praise than that of S. Giorgio. These works, which have often been engraved, must be placed before you, to elucidate what is said. I will only add a few words.
Palladio was thoroughly imbued with the antique mode of existence, and felt the narrow, petty spirit of his own age, like a great man who will not give way to it, but strives to mould all that it leaves him, as far as possible, into accordance with his own ideas. From a slight perusal of his book I conclude that he was displeased with the continued practice of building Christian churches after the form of the ancient Basilica, and, therefore, sought to make his own sacred edifices approximate to the form of the antique temple. Hence arose certain discrepancies, which, as it seemed to me, are happily avoided in Il Redentore, but are rather obvious in the S. Giorgio. Volckmann says something about it, but does not hit the nail on the head.
The interior of Il Redentore is likewise admirable. Everything, including even the designs of the altars, is by Palladio. Unfortunately, the niches, which should have been filled with statues, are glaring with wooden figures, flat, carved, and painted.

October 3.
In honour of S. Francis, S. Peter's capuchins have splendidly adorned a side altar. There was nothing to be seen of stone but the Corinthian capitals; all the rest seemed to be covered with tasteful but splendid embroidery, in the arabesque style, and the effect was as pretty as could be desired. I particularly admired the broad tendrils and foliage, embroidered in gold. Going nearer, I discovered an ingenious deception. All that I had taken for gold was, in fact, straw pressed flat, and glued upon paper, according to some beautiful outlines, while the ground was painted with lively colours. This is done with such variety and tact, that the design, which was probably worked in the convent itself, with a material that was worth nothing, must have cost several thousand dollars, if the material had been genuine. It might on occasion be advantageously imitated.
On one of the quays, and in front of the water I have often remarked a little fellow telling stories in the Venetian dialect, to a greater or less concourse of auditors. Unfortunately I cannot understand a word, but I observe that no one laughs, though the audience, who are composed of the lowest class, occasionally smile. There is nothing striking or ridiculous in the man's appearance, but, on the contrary, something very sedate, with such admirable variety and precision in his gestures, that they evince art and reflection.

October 3.
With my plan in my hand I endeavored to find my way through the strangest labyrinth to the church of the Mendicanti. Here is the conservatorium, which stands in the highest repute at the present day. The ladies performed an oratorio behind the grating, the church was filled with hearers, the music was very beautiful, and the voices were magnificent. An alto sung the part of King Saul, the chief personage in the poem. Of such a voice I had no notion whatever; some passages of the music were excessively beautiful, and the words, which were Latin, most laughably Italianized in some places, were perfectly adapted for singing. Music here has a wide field.
The performance would have been a source of great enjoyment, if the accursed Maestro di Capella had not beaten time with a roll of music against the grating, as conspicuously as if he had to do with school-boys, whom he was instructing. As the girls had repeated the piece often enough, his noise was quite unnecessary, and destroyed all impression, as much as he would, who, in order to make a beautiful statue intelligible to us, should stick scarlet patches on the joints. The foreign sound destroys all harmony. Now this man is a musician, and yet he seems not to be sensible of this; or, more properly speaking, he chooses to let his presence be known by an impropriety, when it would have been much better to allow his value to be perceived by the perfection of the execution. I know that this is the fault of the French, but I did not give the Italians credit for it, and yet the public seems accustomed to it. This is not the first time that that which spoils enjoyment, has been supposed to belong directly to it.

FROM VERONA TO VENICE.
Verona, Sept. 16th.
Well then, the amphitheatre is the first important monument of the old times that I have seen—and how well it is preserved! When I entered, and still more when I walked round the edge of it at the top, it seemed strange to me, that I saw something great, and yet, properly speaking, saw nothing. Besides I do not like to see it empty, I should like to see it full of people, just as, in modern times, it was filled up in honour of Joseph I. and Pius VI. The Emperor, although his eye was accustomed to human masses, must have been astonished. But it was only in the earliest times, that it produced its full effect, when the people was more a people than it is now. For, properly speaking, such an amphitheatre is constructed to give the people an imposing view of itself,—to cajole itself.
When anything worth seeing occurs on the level ground, and any one runs to the spot, the hindermost try by every means to raise themselves above the foremost; they get upon benches, roll casks, bring up vehicles, lay planks in every direction, occupy the neighbouring heights, and a crater is formed in no time.
If the spectacle occur frequently on the same spot, light scaffoldings are built for those who are able to pay, and the rest of the multitude must get on as it can. Here the problem of the architect is to satisfy this general want. By means of his art he prepares such a crater, making it as simple as possible, that the people itself may constitute the decoration. When the populace saw itself so assembled, it must have been astonished at the sight, for whereas it was only accustomed to see itself running about in confusion, or to find itself crowded together without particular rule or order, so must this many-headed, many-minded, wandering animal now see itself combined into a noble body, made into a definite unity, bound and secured into a mass, and animated as one form by one mind. The simplicity of the oval is most pleasingly obvious to every eye, and every head serves as a measure to show the vastness of the whole. Now we see it empty, we have no standard, and do not know whether it is large or small.
The Veronese deserve commendation for the high preservation in which this edifice is kept. It is built of a reddish marble, which has been affected by the atmosphere, and hence the steps which have been eaten, are continually restored, and look almost all new. An inscription makes mention of one Hieronymus Maurigenus, and of the incredible industry, which he has expended on this monument. Of the outer wall only a piece remains, and I doubt whether it was ever quite finished. The lower arches, which adjoin the large square, called "Il Bra," are let out to workmen, and the reanimation of these arcades produces a cheerful appearance.

Verona, Sept. 16.
The most beautiful gate, which, however, always remains closed, is called "Porta stupa," or "del Pallio." As a gate, and considering the great distance from which it is first seen, it is not well conceived, and it is not till we come near it, that we recognise the beauty of the structure.
All sorts of reasons are given to account for its being closed. I have, however, a conjecture of my own. It was manifestly the intention of the artist to cause a new Corso to be laid out from this gate, for the situation, or the present street, is completely wrong. On the left side there is nothing but barracks; and the line at right angles from the middle of the gate leads to a convent of nuns, which must certainly have come down. This was presently perceived, and besides the rich and higher classes might not have liked to settle in the remote quarter. The artist perhaps died, and therefore the door was closed, and so an end was put to the affair.

Verona, Sept. 16.
The portico of the theatre, consisting of six large Ionic columns, looks handsome enough. So much the more puny is the appearance of the Marchese di Maffei's bust, which as large as life, and in a great wig, stands over the door, and in front of a painted niche, which is supported by two Corinthian columns. The position is honorable, but to be in some degree proportionate to the magnitude and solidity of the columns, the bust should have been colossal. But now placed as it is on a corbel, it has a mean appearance, and is by no means in harmony with the whole.
The gallery, which incloses the fore-court, is also small, and the channelled Doric dwarfs have a mean appearance by the side of the smooth Ionic giants. But we pardon this discrepancy on account of the fine institution, which has been founded among the columns. Here is kept a number of antiquities, which have mostly been dug up in and about Verona. Something, they say, has even been found in the Amphitheatre. There are Etruscan, Greek, and Roman specimens, down to the latest times, and some even of more modern date. The bas-reliefs are inserted in the walls, and provided with the numbers, which Maffei gave them, when he described them in his work: "Verona illustrata." There are altars, fragments of columns, and other relics of the sort; an admirable tripod of white marble, upon which there are genii occupied with the attributes of the gods. Raphael has imitated and improved this kind of thing in the scrolls of the Farnesina.
The wind which blows from the graves of the ancients, comes fragrantly over hills of roses. The tombs give touching evidences of a genuine feeling, and always bring life back to us. Here is a man, by the side of his wife, who peeps out of a niche, as if it were a window. Here are father and mother, with their son between them, eyeing each other as naturally as possible. Here a couple are grasping each other's hands. Here a father, resting on his couch, seems to be amused by his family. The immediate proximity of these stones was to me highly touching. They belong to a later school of art, but are simple, natural, and generally pleasing. Here a man in armour is on his knees in expectation of a joyful resurrection. With more or less of talent the artist has produced the mere simple presence of the persons, and has thus given a permanent continuation to their existence. They do not fold their hands, they do not look towards heaven, but they are here below just what they were and just what they are. They stand together, take interest in each other, love one another, and this is charmingly expressed on the stone, though with a certain want of technical skill. A marble pillar, very richly adorned, gave me more new ideas.
Laudable as this institution is, we can plainly perceive that the noble spirit of preservation, by which it was founded, is no longer continued. The valuable tripod will soon be ruined, placed as it is in the open air, and exposed to the weather towards the west. This treasure might easily be preserved in a wooden case.
The palace of the Proveditore, which is begun, might have afforded a fine specimen of architecture, if it had been finished. Generally speaking, the nobili build a great deal, but unfortunately every one builds on the site of his former residence, and often, therefore, in narrow lanes. Thus, for instance, a magnificent façade to a seminary is now building in an alley of tire remotest suburb.

While, with a guide, whom I had accidentally picked up, I passed before the great solemn gate of a singular building, he asked me good-humouredly, whether I should not like to step into the court for a while. It was the palace of justice, and the court, on account of the height of the building, looked only like an enormous wall. Here, he told me, all the criminals and suspicious persons are confined. I looked around, and saw that round all the stories there were open passages' fitted with iron balustrades, which passed by numerous doors. The prisoner, as he stepped out of his dungeon to be led to trial, stood in the open air, and was exposed to the gaze of all passers, and because there were several trial-rooms, the chains were rattling, now over this, now over that passage, in every story. It was a hateful sight, and I do not deny that the good humour, with which I had dispatched my "Birds," might here have come into a strait.

I walked at sunset upon the margin of the crater-like amphitheatre, and enjoyed the most splendid prospect over the town and the surrounding country. I was quite alone, and multitudes of people were passing below me on the hard stones of the Bra; men of all ranks, and women of the middle-ranks were walking. The latter in their black outer garments look, in this bird's-eye view, like so many mummies.
The Zendale and the Veste, which serves this class in the place of an entire wardrobe, is a costume completely fitted for a people that does not care much for cleanliness, and yet always likes to appear in public, sometimes at church, sometimes on the promenade. The Veste is a gown of black taffeta, which is thrown over other gowns. If the lady has a clean white one beneath, she contrives to lift up the black one on one side. This is fastened on so, as to cut the waist, and to cover the lappets of a corset, which may be of any colour. The Zendale is a large hood with long ears; the hood itself is kept high above the head by a wire-frame, while the ears are fastened round the body like a scarf, so that the ends fall down behind.

Verona, Sept. 16.
When I again left the Arena to-day, I came to a modern public spectacle, about a thousand paces from the spot. Four noble Veronese were playing ball against four people of Vicenza. This pastime is carried on among the Veronese themselves all the year round, about two hours before night. On this occasion there was a far larger concourse of people than usual, on account of the foreign adversaries. The spectators seem to have amounted to four or five thousand. I did not see women of any rank.
When, a little while ago, I spoke of the necessities of the multitude in such a case, I described the natural accidental amphitheatre as arising just in the manner, in which I saw the people raised one over another on this occasion. Even at a distance I could hear the lively clapping of hands, which accompanied every important stroke. The game is played as follows: Two boards, slightly inclined, are placed at a convenient distance from each other. He who strikes off the ball stands at the higher end, his right hand is armed with a broad wooden ring, set with spikes. While another of his party throws the ball to him, he runs down to meet it, and thus increases the force of the blow with which he strikes it. The adversaries try to beat it back, and thus it goes backwards and forwards till, at last, it remains on the ground. The most beautiful attitudes, worthy of being imitated in marble, are thus produced. As there are none but well-grown active young people, in a short, close, white dress, the parties are only distinguished by a yellow mark. Particularly beautiful is the attitude into which the man on the eminence falls, when he runs down the inclined plain, and raises his arm to strike the ball;—it approaches that of the Borghesian gladiator.
It seemed strange to me that they carry on this exercise by an old lime-wall, without the slightest convenience for spectators; why is it not done in the amphitheatre, where there would be such ample room?

Verona, September 17.
What I have seen of pictures I will but briefly touch upon, and add some remarks. I do not make this extraordinary tour for the sake of deceiving myself, but to become acquainted with myself by means of these objects. I therefore honestly confess that of the painter's art—of his manipulation, I understand but little. My attention, and observation, can only be directed to the practical part, to the subject, and the general treatment of it.
S. Georgio is a gallery of good pictures, all altar-pieces, and all remarkable, if not of equal value. But what subjects were the hapless artists obliged to paint? And for whom? Perhaps a shower of manna thirty feet long, and twenty feet high, with the miracle of the loaves as a companion. What could be made of these subjects? Hungry men falling on little grains, and a countless multitude of others, to whom bread is handed. The artists have racked their invention in order to get something striking out of such wretched subjects. And yet, stimulated by the urgency of the case, genius has produced some beautiful things. An artist, who had to paint S. Ursula with the eleven thousand virgins, has got over the difficulty cleverly enough. The saint stands in the foreground, as if she had conquered the country. She is very noble, like an Amazonia's virgin, and without any enticing charms; on the other hand, her troop is shown descending from the ships, and moving in procession at a diminishing distance. The Assumption of the Virgin, by Titian, in the dome, has become much blackened, and it is a thought worthy of praise that, at the moment of her apotheosis, she looks not towards heaven, but towards her friends below.
In the Gherardini Gallery I found some very fine things by Orbitto, and for the first time became acquainted with this meritorious artist. At a distance we only hear of the first artists, and then we are often contented with names only; but when we draw nearer to this starry sky, and the luminaries of the second and third magnitude also begin to twinkle, each one coming forward and occupying his proper place in the whole constellation, then the world becomes wide, and art becomes rich. I must here commend the conception of one of the pictures. Sampson has gone to sleep in the lap of Dalilah, and she has softly stretched her hand over him to reach a pair of scissors, which lies near the lamp on the table. The execution is admirable. In the Canopa Palace I observed a Danäe.
The Bevilagua Palace contains the most valuable things. A picture by Tintoretto, which is called a "Paradise," but which, in fact, represents the Coronation of the Virgin Mary as Queen of Heaven, in the presence of all the patriarchs, prophets, apostles, saints, angels, &c., affords an opportunity for displaying all the riches of the most felicitous genius. To admire and enjoy all that care of manipulation, that spirit and variety of expression, it is necessary to possess the picture, and to have it before one all one's life. The painter's work is carried on ad infinitum,; even the farthest angels' heads, which are vanishing in the halo, preserve something of character. The largest figures may be about a foot high; Mary, and the Christ who is crowning her, about four inches. Eve is, however, the finest woman in the picture; a little voluptuous, as from time immemorial.
A couple of portraits by Paul Veronese have only increased my veneration for that artist. The collection of antiquities is very fine; there is a son of Niobe extended in death, which is highly valuable; and the busts, including an Augustus with the civic crown, a Caligula, and others, are mostly of great interest, notwithstanding the restoration of the noses.
It lies in my nature to admire, willingly and joyfully, all that is great and beautiful, and the cultivation of this talent, day after day, hour after hour, by the inspection of such beautiful objects, produces the happiest feelings.
In a land, where we enjoy the days but take especial delight in the evenings, the time of nightfall is highly important. For now work ceases; those who have gone out walking turn back; the father wishes to have his daughter home again; the day has an end. What the day is we Cimmerians hardly know. In our eternal mist and fog it is the same thing to us, whether it be day or night, for how much time can we really pass and enjoy in the open air? Now, when night sets in, the day, which consisted of a morning and an evening, is decidedly past, four and twenty hours are gone, the bells ring, the rosary is taken in hand, and the maid, entering the chamber with the lighted lamp, says, "felicissima notte." This epoch varies with every season, and a man who lives here in actual life cannot go wrong, because all the enjoyments of his existence are regulated not by the nominal hour, but by the time of day. If the people were forced to use a German clock they would be perplexed, for their own is intimately connected with their nature. About an hour and a half, or an hour before midnight, the nobility begin to ride out. They proceed to the Piazza della Bra, along the long, broad street to the Porta Nuova out at the gate, and along the city, and when night sets in, they all return home. Sometimes they go to the churches to say their Ave Maria della sera: sometimes they keep on the Bra, where the cavaliers step up to the coaches and converse for a while with the ladies. The foot passengers remain till a late hour of night, but I have never stopped till the last. To-day just enough rain had fallen to lay the dust, and the spectacle was most cheerful and animated.
That I may accommodate myself the better to the custom of the country I have devised a plan for mastering more easily the Italian method of reckoning the hours. The accompanying diagram may give an idea of it. The inner circle denotes our four and twenty hours, from midnight to midnight, divided into twice twelve, as we reckon, and as our clocks indicate. The middle circle shows how the clocks strike at the present season, namely, as much as twelve twice in the twenty-four hours, but in such a way that it strikes one, when it strikes eight with us, and so on till the number twelve is complete. At eight o'clock in the morning according to our clock it again strikes one, and so on. Finally the outer circle shows how the four and twenty hours are reckoned in actual life. For example, I hear seven o'clock striking in the night, and know that midnight is at five o'clock; I therefore deduct the latter number from the former, and thus have two hours after midnight. If I hear seven o'clock strike in the day-time, and know that noon is at five, I proceed in the same way, and thus have two in the afternoon. But if I wish to express the hour according to the fashion of this country, I must know that noon is seventeen o'clock; I add the two, and get nineteen o'clock. When this method is heard and thought of for the first time, it seems extremely confused and difficult to manage, but we soon grow accustomed to it and find the occupation amusing. The people themselves take delight in this perpetual calculation, just as children are pleased with easily surmounted difficulties. Indeed they always have their fingers in the air, make any calculation in their heads, and like to occupy themselves with figures. Besides to the inhabitant of the country the matter is so much the easier, as he really does not trouble himself about noon and midnight, and does not, like the foreign resident, compare two clocks with each other. They only count from the evening the hours, as they strike, and in the day-time they add the number to the varying number of noon, with which they are acquainted. Verona, Sept. 17.
The people here jostle one another actively enough; the narrow streets, where shops and workmen's stalls are thickly crowded together, have a particularly cheerful look. There is no such thing as a door in front of the shop or workroom; the whole breadth of the house is open, and one may see all that passes in the interior. Half-way out into the path, the tailors are sewing; and the cobblers are pulling and rapping; indeed the work-stalls make a part of the street. In the evening, when the lights are burning, the appearance is most lively.
The squares are very full on market days; there are fruit and vegetables without number, and garlic and onions to the heart's desire. Then again throughout the day there is a ceaseless screaming, bantering, singing, squalling, huzzaing, and laughing. The mildness of the air, and the cheapness of the food, make subsistence easy. Everything possible is done in the open air.
At night singing and all sorts of noises begin. The ballad of "Marlbrook" is heard in every street;—then comes a dulcimer, then a violin. They try to imitate all the birds with a pipe. The strangest sounds are heard on every side. A mild climate can give this exquisite enjoyment of mere existence, even to poverty, and the very shadow of the people seems respectable.
The want of cleanliness and convenience, which so much strikes us in the houses, arises from the following cause:—the inhabitants are always out of doors, and in their light-heartedness think of nothing. With the people all goes right, even the middle-class man just lives on from day to day, while the rich and genteel shut themselves up in their dwellings, which are not so habitable as in the north. Society is found in the open streets. Fore-courts and colonnades are all soiled with filth, for things are done in the most natural manner. The people always feel their way before them. The rich man may be rich, and build his palaces; and the nobile may rule, but if he makes a colonnade or a fore-court, the people will make use of it for their own occasions, and have no more urgent wish than to get rid as soon as possible, of that which they have taken as often as possible. If a person cannot bear this, he must not play the great gentleman, that is to say, he must act as if a part of his dwelling belonged to the public. He may shut his door, and all will be right. But in open buildings the people are not to be debarred of their privileges, and this, throughout Italy, is a nuisance to the foreigner.
To-day I remarked in several streets of the town, the customs and manners of the middle-classes especially, who appear very numerous and busy. They swing their arms as they walk. Persons of a high rank, who on certain occasions wear a sword, swing only one arm, being accustomed to hold the left arm still.
Although the people are careless enough with respect to their own wants and occupations, they have a keen eye for everything foreign. Thus in the very first days, I observed that every one took notice of my boots, because here they are too expensive an article of dress to wear even in winter. Now I wear shoes and stockings nobody looks at me. Particularly I noticed this morning, when all were running about with flowers, vegetables, garlic, and other market-stuff, that a twig of cypress, which I carried in my hand, did not escape them. Some green cones hung upon it, and I held in the same hand some blooming caper-twigs. Everybody, large and small, watched me closely, and seemed to entertain some whimsical thought.
I brought these twigs from the Giusti garden, which is finely situated, and in which there are monstrous cypresses, all pointed up like spikes into the air. The Taxus, which in northern gardening we find cut to a sharp point, is probably an imitation of this splendid natural product. A tree, the branches of which, the oldest as well as the youngest, are striving to reach heaven,—a tree which will last its three hundred years, is well worthy of veneration. Judging from the time when this garden was laid out, these trees have already attained that advanced age.

Vicenza, Sept. 19.
The way from Verona hither is very pleasant: we go north-eastwards along the mountains, always keeping to the left the foremost mountains, which consist of sand, lime, clay, and marl; the hills which they form, are dotted with villages, castles, and houses. To the right extends the broad plain, along which the road goes. The straight broad path, which is in good preservation, goes through a fertile field; we look into deep avenues of trees, up which the vines are trained to a considerable height, and then drop down, like pendant branches. Here we can get an admirable idea of festoons! The grapes are ripe, and are heavy on the tendrils, which hang down long and trembling. The road is filled with people of every class and occupation, and I was particularly pleased by some carts, with low solid wheels, which, with teams of fine oxen, carry the large vats, in which the grapes from the vineyards are put and pressed. The drivers rode in them when they were empty, and the whole was like a triumphal procession of Bacchanals. Between the ranks of vines the ground is used for all sorts of grain, especially Indian corn and millet (Sörgel).
As one goes towards Vicenza, the hills again rise from north to south and enclose the plain; they are, it is said, volcanic. Vicenza lies at their foot, or if you will, in a bosom which they form.

Vicenza, Sept. 19.
Though I have been here only a few hours, I have already run through the town, and seen the Olympian theatre, and the buildings of Palladio. A very pretty little book is published here, for the convenience of foreigners, with copper-plates and some letter-press, that shows knowledge of art. When once one stands in the presence of these works, one immediately perceives their great value, for they are calculated to fill the eye with their actual greatness and massiveness, and to satisfy the mind by the beautiful harmony of their dimensions, not only in abstract sketches, but with all the prominences and distances of perspective. Therefore I say of Palladio: he was a man really and intrinsically great, whose greatness was outwardly manifested. The chief difficulty with which this man, like all modern architects, had to struggle, was the suitable application of the orders of columns to buildings for domestic or public use; for there is always a contradiction in the combination of columns and walls. But with what success has he not worked them up together! What an imposing effect has the aspect of his edifices: at the sight of them one almost forgets that he is attempting to reconcile us to a violation of the rules of his art. There is, indeed, something divine about his designs, which may be exactly compared to the creations of the great poet, who, out of truth and falsehood elaborates something between both, and charms us with its borrowed existence.
The Olympic theatre is a theatre of the ancients, realized on a small scale, and indescribably beautiful. However, compared with our theatres, it reminds me of a genteel, rich, well-bred child, contrasted with a shrewd man of the world, who, though he is neither so rich, nor so genteel, and well-bred, knows better how to employ his resources.
If we contemplate, on the spot, the noble buildings which Palladio has erected, and see how they are disfigured by the mean filthy necessities of the people, how the plans of most of them exceeded the means of those who undertook them, and how little these precious monuments of one lofty mind are adapted to all else around, the thought occurs, that it is just the same with everything else; for we receive but little thanks from men, when we would elevate their internal aspirations, give them a great idea of themselves, and make them feel the grandeur of a really noble existence. But when one cajoles them, tells them tales, and helping them on from day to day, makes them worse, then one is just the man they like; and hence it is that modern times take delight in so many absurdities. I do not say this to lower my friends, I only say that they are so, and that people must not be astonished to find everything just as it is.
How the Basilica of Palladio looks by the side of an old castellated kind of a building, dotted all over with windows of different sizes (whose removal, tower and all, the artist evidently contemplated),—it is impossible to describe—and besides I must now, by a strange effort, compress my own feelings, for, I too, alas! find here side by side both what I seek and what I fly from.

Sept. 20.
Yesterday we had the opera, which lasted till midnight, and I was glad to get some rest. The three Sultanesses and the Rape of the Seraglio have afforded several tatters, out of which the piece has been patched up, with very little skill. The music is agreeable to the ear, but is probably by an amateur; for not a single thought struck me as being new. The ballets, on the other hand, were charming. The principle pair of dancers executed an Allemande to perfection.
